<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 348, 293]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0606/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 268, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Non-calculator  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- Calculators must not be used in this paper.- You must show all necessary working clearly.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 213, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 107, 477, 126]]<|/det|>
Equation of a circle with centre \((a, b)\) and radius \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[601, 102, 784, 123]]<|/det|>
\((x - a)^2 + (y - b)^2 = r^2\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 153, 626, 172]]<|/det|>
Curved surface area, \(A\), of cone of radius \(r\), sloping edge \(l\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[606, 153, 675, 171]]<|/det|>
\(A = \pi r l\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 201, 680, 220]]<|/det|>
Surface area, \(A\), of sphere of radius \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[606, 200, 680, 218]]<|/det|>
\(A = 4\pi r^2\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 247, 680, 270]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V,\) of pyramid or cone, base area \(A\), height \(h\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[606, 243, 680, 271]]<|/det|>
\(V = \frac{1}{3} Ah\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 297, 680, 317]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V,\) of sphere of radius \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[606, 292, 680, 317]]<|/det|>
\(V = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 345, 234, 364]]<|/det|>
Quadratic equation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 345, 656, 364]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(a x^{2} + b x + c = 0\),

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 365, 561, 400]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 444, 227, 463]]<|/det|>
Binomial theorem

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 435, 910, 477]]<|/det|>
\((a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n},\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 482, 771, 523]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 553, 218, 571]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 552, 670, 595]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{array}{l}{u_{n} = a + (n - 1)d}\\ {S_{n} = \frac{1}{2} n(a + l) = \frac{1}{2} n\{2a + (n - 1)d\}} \end{array}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 630, 218, 648]]<|/det|>
Geometric series

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 628, 574, 710]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{array}{l}{u_{n} = a r^{n - 1}}\\ {S_{n} = \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r} (r\neq 1)}\\ {S_{\infty} = \frac{a}{1 - r} (|r|< 1)} \end{array}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 739, 158, 757]]<|/det|>
Identities

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 737, 556, 789]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{array}{l}\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\\ \sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\\ \cosec^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A \end{array}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 828, 240, 846]]<|/det|>
Formulas for \(\Delta ABC\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 821, 578, 900]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{array}{l}\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C}\\ a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\\ \Delta = \frac{1}{2} ab\sin C \end{array}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[330, 72, 667, 88]]<|/det|>
Calculators must **not** be used in this paper.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 101, 856, 320]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 350, 697, 368]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the graph of \(y = |\operatorname {f}(x)|\), where f is a cubic polynomial.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 364, 529, 383]]<|/det|>
Find expressions for the two possible functions \(\operatorname {f}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 380, 484, 397]]<|/det|>
Write each expression in fully factorised form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 381, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 648, 94]]<|/det|>
A circle with centre \(C\) has the equation \(x^{2} + y^{2} - 10x - 4y + 24 = 0.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 107, 144, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 107, 604, 127]]<|/det|>
Show that the line \(y = 2x - 3\) is a tangent to this circle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 107, 918, 125]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 308, 146, 327]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 308, 792, 327]]<|/det|>
Given that this tangent touches the circle at the point \(P\), find the coordinates of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 308, 920, 327]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 448, 143, 466]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 447, 823, 466]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the circle which has its centre at \(P\) and passes through the origin.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 447, 920, 466]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 94, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 79, 146, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 75, 301, 102]]<|/det|>
Find \(\int_{0}^{\pi} \sin \theta \mathrm{d}\theta .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 78, 918, 100]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 297, 146, 316]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 291, 730, 320]]<|/det|>
Given that \(0 < \alpha < \frac{\pi}{2}\), show that \(\frac{\sec \alpha}{\cot \alpha + \tan \alpha}\) can be written as \(\sin \alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 295, 920, 314]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 798, 96]]<|/det|>
The polynomial p is such that \(\mathrm{p}(x) = 3x^{3} - 7x^{2} + ax + b\) , where \(a\) and \(b\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 107, 606, 127]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\mathrm{p}'( - 1) = 21\) and that \(x - 2\) is a factor of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 139, 144, 158]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 139, 366, 158]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 139, 920, 158]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 416, 146, 435]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 416, 717, 435]]<|/det|>
Hence write \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) as a product of linear factors with integer coefficients.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 416, 920, 435]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 586, 144, 604]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 586, 755, 604]]<|/det|>
Using your values of \(a\) and \(b\), solve the equation \(3\mathrm{e}^{6y} - 7\mathrm{e}^{4y} + a\mathrm{e}^{2y} + b = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 586, 920, 604]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 920, 95]]<|/det|>
When \(\ln y\) is plotted against \(x^{3}\), a straight line passing through the points (2, 5) and \((- 8, 25)\) is obtained.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 107, 146, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 107, 316, 125]]<|/det|>
Find \(y\) in terms of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 107, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 400, 146, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 400, 423, 419]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(x\) when \(y = \mathrm{e}^{25}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 400, 920, 419]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 94, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 77, 883, 106]]<|/det|>
A geometric progression has a 4th term of \(\frac{8k^6}{27}\) and a 6th term of \(\frac{32k^{10}}{243}\), where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 112, 584, 133]]<|/det|>
The common ratio of this geometric progression is positive.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 144, 146, 163]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 144, 920, 165]]<|/det|>
Find the common ratio in terms of \(k\) and the value of the first term of this geometric progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 163, 920, 180]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 516, 146, 535]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 515, 920, 536]]<|/det|>
Given that this geometric progression has a sum to infinity of 3, find the possible values of \(k\). [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 84, 94, 103]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 388, 106]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(y = \frac{\ln(3x^2 + 16)}{x + 2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 109, 146, 128]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 109, 326, 133]]<|/det|>
Find \(\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}\) when \(x = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 144, 601, 165]]<|/det|>
Give your answer in the form \(\ln p\), where \(p\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 144, 920, 163]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 535, 146, 553]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 535, 923, 555]]<|/det|>
Given that \(x\) increases from 0 to \(h\), where \(h\) is small, write down the approximate change in \(y\). [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 646, 94]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\mathrm{f}(x) = 2\ln (3x - 4)\) , for \(x > a\), and that \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}\) exists.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 107, 144, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 107, 420, 126]]<|/det|>
Find the least possible value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 107, 918, 125]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 184, 144, 203]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 184, 462, 203]]<|/det|>
For your value of \(a\), find the range of f.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 184, 918, 203]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 279, 144, 297]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 279, 549, 297]]<|/det|>
For your value of \(a\), find an expression for \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 279, 918, 297]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 386, 146, 404]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 386, 594, 404]]<|/det|>
It is given that the equation \(\mathrm{f}(x) = \mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\) has two roots.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 416, 771, 435]]<|/det|>
For your value of \(a\), sketch the graphs of \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\) and \(y = \mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\) on the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 448, 297, 465]]<|/det|>
Label each graph.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 463, 529, 482]]<|/det|>
State the intercepts of each graph with the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 479, 457, 497]]<|/det|>
State the equations of any asymptotes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 479, 920, 497]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 510, 856, 792]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[314, 81, 680, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 272, 448, 292]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the shape \(OABCDEF\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 288, 292, 306]]<|/det|>
\(AOF\) is a straight line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 303, 616, 323]]<|/det|>
\(OAB\) and \(OEF\) are sectors of a circle with centre \(O\) and radius \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 319, 324, 338]]<|/det|>
Angle \(BOA =\) angle \(EOF.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 345, 556, 368]]<|/det|>
\(OCD\) is a sector of a circle with centre \(O\) and radius \(\frac{4r}{3}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 380, 316, 399]]<|/det|>
Angle \(COD\) is \(\theta\) radians.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 395, 641, 415]]<|/det|>
The point \(B\) lies on the line \(OC\) and the point \(E\) lies on the line \(OD\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 411, 425, 430]]<|/det|>
The line \(BE\) is parallel to the line \(AOF\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 443, 144, 460]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 443, 645, 462]]<|/det|>
Find, in terms of \(r\) and \(\theta\) , the area of the shaded region \(BCDE\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 444, 920, 462]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 143, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 81, 680, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 717, 291]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the shape from part (a) with region \(OABEF\) shaded.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 630, 306]]<|/det|>
Find, in terms of \(r\) and \(\theta\), the perimeter of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 288, 920, 306]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 101, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[138, 85, 856, 298]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 313, 668, 336]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the triangle \(OAB\), where \(\overrightarrow{OA} = \mathbf{a}\) and \(\overrightarrow{OB} = \mathbf{b}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 343, 485, 368]]<|/det|>
The point \(P\) lies on \(OA\) such that \(\overrightarrow{OP} = \frac{3}{4}\overrightarrow{OA}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 371, 485, 399]]<|/det|>
The point \(Q\) lies on \(AB\) such that \(\overrightarrow{AQ} = \frac{1}{3}\overrightarrow{AB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 406, 803, 428]]<|/det|>
The straight line through \(P\) and \(Q\) meets the straight line through \(O\) and \(B\) at the point \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 425, 712, 446]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\overrightarrow{OR} = \lambda \mathbf{b}\) and \(\overrightarrow{PR} = \mu \overrightarrow{PQ}\), where \(\lambda\) and \(\mu\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 472, 144, 490]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 471, 411, 491]]<|/det|>
Find \(\overrightarrow{OR}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{b}\) and \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 473, 918, 491]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 425, 91]]<|/det|>
Hence find the values of \(\lambda\) and \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 91]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 724, 665, 742]]<|/det|>
Question 12 is printed on the next page.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 78, 104, 96]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 76, 682, 100]]<|/det|>
A curve is such that its gradient at the point \((x, y)\) is given by \((5x - 2)^{\frac{1}{3}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 106, 463, 133]]<|/det|>
The curve passes through the point \(\left(2, \frac{32}{5}\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 139, 561, 163]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of the stationary point on the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 140, 920, 159]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]
